awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling Strategic Regulators in Network Infrastructure Planning
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale infrastructure systems (e.g. gas, power, and water networks) often cross local, regional, and national jurisdiction boundaries. When this is the case, each jurisdiction oversees a certain part of the entire infrastructure system and can elect to pursue its own socio-economic objectives using different policy instruments. Such a jurisdictional divide naturally creates a fertile environment for regulatory competition. This project will develop mathematical models that study implications of this competition on the optimal infrastructure design. As an example, it will focus on electric power networks that are currently undergoing a rapid transition toward smart grids. If successful, this project will provide tools for infrastructure operators and planners (e.g. power utilities and state/federal regulators), as well as citizens, to evaluate the effects of different regulatory structures on achieving policy objectives. Project outcomes will be conveyed by means of direct outreach and via professional workshops, conferences, and peer-reviewed publications. Furthermore, broader impacts include training of future STEM researchers at graduate and undergraduate levels via project mentorship, independent research studies, and research-informed improvements to existing courses, as well as early-stage research opportunities for local high-school students from underrepresented groups in STEM (via NYU's Applied Research Innovations in Science and Engineering program).

This project will develop formal mathematical models for optimizing policy decisions for large-scale, hierarchical, network-constrained infrastructure systems. This model will endogenously optimize policy decisions that are currently considered as exogenous parameters in infrastructure planning tasks and allow for studying different forms of regulatory competition between multiple jurisdictions. To represent this competition and account for all aspects of infrastructure operating and planning tasks, the project will leverage the multi-leader-common-follower game-theoretic framework.   This framework is notoriously known to be computationally demanding and, therefore, this project will develop scalable algorithmic solutions, based on the Progressive Hedging algorithm, to implement the framework for realistically large networks. The algorithmic component of this project will investigate solution quality, e.g. its optimality and uniqueness properties. Broader scientific impacts are anticipated in models and algorithms to solve multi-stage optimization problems under uncertainty. This project will directly benefit researchers and developers working in the area of operations research and smart grids/cities, with extensions relevant to public policy and network economics communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project achieved significant advances in understanding and improving energy policy decision-making and market dynamics. The research focused on developing a comprehensive modeling framework to evaluate energy policy instruments and optimize their implementation in real-world settings (e.g., as US states strive to achieve state-level renewable energy goals while exploiting the same physical - transmission network - infrastructure)

The team created an optimization model capable of incorporating policy decisions using three primary instruments: command-and-control, economic incentives, and hybrid approaches. These instruments were analyzed through an Equilibrium Problem with Equilibrium Constraints (EPEC), designed to capture the strategic behavior of regulators. The EPEC was reformulated into bilevel programs to represent the actions of individual strategic actors. By leveraging the ISO New England testbed, the team ran simulations to compare the efficiency and performance of these policy instruments in achieving objectives such as renewable energy portfolio standards. Initial results revealed that the strategic behavior of regional regulators influences the choice and effectiveness of policy instruments, underscoring the importance of considering these dynamics in policy design. To address the computational challenges of solving non-convex stochastic problems inherent in EPEC formulations, the team customized a Progressive Hedging algorithm. This algorithm was further refined to improve its performance when applied to network-constrained optimization problems, including power flow analyses under operational and design uncertainties. A key outcome of this work was the derivation of a closed-form expression for selecting optimal hedging multipliers, which improved computational efficiency while preserving solution accuracy.

The research also explored the effects of granular and equitable energy tariff designs on economic efficiency and equity in electric power distribution. A justice-focused tariff design framework was developed to incorporate socio-economic and demographic characteristics of electricity consumers. Using the New York ISO and Manhattan power networks, simulations demonstrated that spatially- and temporally-granular tariffs not only improved economic efficiency but also reduced energy burdens for consumers, highlighting the potential for more equitable outcomes in energy policymaking. Additionally, the team investigated the role of information asymmetry in distributed energy resource (DER) compensation policies. By developing a game-theoretic framework, the research demonstrated that granular compensation mechanisms, such as value stack pricing, reflect the true value of DERs more accurately than traditional approaches. These policies resulted in more efficient market outcomes and reduced the need for out-of-market interventions. Furthermore, incorporating carbon pricing into these compensation schemes led to the highest social welfare, providing clear evidence for the benefits of integrated, granular policy designs.


Beyond these research achievements, the project prioritized broader impacts by engaging with diverse audiences and fostering inclusivity. Several Ph.D. students were supported by the project and were also engaged with mentoring K-12 students from underrepresented backgrounds in STEM fields. Over several summers, the team hosted high school students, introducing them to energy research and modeling. This initiative not only provided hands-on learning opportunities but also inspired the next generation of scientists and engineers.

The research team also engaged actively with policymakers and stakeholders. Regular communication with collaborators, such as Prof. Frank Felder at Rutgers, ensured that the research was aligned with real-world needs. The team’s findings were shared with local policymakers, including the New York City Council, to inform decisions on energy justice and efficient market designs. Insights from the project were integrated into graduate courses, enhancing the educational experience for students and preparing them for future challenges in the energy sector.

The project contributed to the graduation of 4 Ph.D. students from NYU and JHU, enabling at least 12 M.Sc. and undergraduate research projects. The project results in 21 publications and 36 related research presentations.
